name: Traced

types.name: Traced
types.comment:
Pack together an accumulator, a unique value,
and a function to view the value.

Accumulates new values together in most operations.

This is very similar to `Store a b`.
The difference being that a `Traced a b` accumulates the `a`
as it unfolds all future states,
whereas a `Store a b` replaces all `a`s as it unfolds all future states.

values.name: addition
values.comment:
Creates a traced that accumulates with addition.

The unique value is 0.
values.type: Traced.Traced number number

values.name: duplicate
values.comment:
Create a new traced where the view is another traced.

Gives us the lazy unfolding of all future states of a given traced.
values.type: Traced.Traced m a -> Traced.Traced m (Traced.Traced m a)

values.name: extract
values.comment: View the current value.
values.type: Traced.Traced m a -> a

values.name: list
values.comment:
Creates a traced that accumulates lists.

The unique value is the empty list.
values.type: Traced.Traced (List a) (List a)

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the view.

Useful when you want to change the view of an already defined traced.
values.type: (a -> b) -> Traced.Traced m a -> Traced.Traced m b

values.name: move
values.comment:
Move to the new given value.

This is how we make progress in the UI.
values.type: m -> Traced.Traced m a -> Traced.Traced m a

values.name: multiplication
values.comment:
Creates a traced that accumulates with multiplication.

The unique value is 1.
values.type: Traced.Traced number number

values.name: set
values.comment:
Replace the view.

A common pattern is to just replace the old view without depending on it:
`set x = map (\_ -> x)`
values.type: b -> Traced.Traced m a -> Traced.Traced m b

values.name: string
values.comment:
Creates a traced that accumulates strings.

The unique value is the empty string.
values.type: Traced.Traced String String

values.name: toBeginnerProgram
values.comment:
Convert to a "beginner program" for use in a `main` function

    import Html exposing (Html)
    import Html.Events
    import String.Extra
    import Traced exposing (Traced)

    main : Program Never (Traced Int (Html Int)) Int
    main =
        Html.beginnerProgram
            (Traced.toBeginnerProgram (Traced.map view Traced.addition))

    view : Int -> Html Int
    view n =
        Html.div
            []
            [ Html.button
                [ Html.Events.onClick -1 ]
                [ Html.text "-" ]
            , Html.div
                []
                [ Html.text (String.Extra.fromInt n) ]
            , Html.button
                [ Html.Events.onClick 1 ]
                [ Html.text "+" ]
            ]

View this example on Ellie: <https://ellie-app.com/Mx3LhD8Fa1/0>
values.type: Traced.Traced m (Html.Html a) -> { model : Traced.Traced m (Html.Html a) , update : m -> Traced.Traced m (Html.Html a) -> Traced.Traced m (Html.Html a) , view : Traced.Traced m (Html.Html a) -> Html.Html a }

values.name: view
values.comment:
Returns the view of a traced.

Useful when you want to view the value,
with something other than the unique value of the traced.
values.type: Traced.Traced m a -> m -> a

name: Store

aliases.name: Store
aliases.comment:
Pack together the current value along with a function to view said value.

We can specialize the `a` to be `Html a`
and get something that works for top level programs.

We can also not do that.
We can describe many UIs and they don't have to be `Html a`.

values.name: duplicate
values.comment:
Create a new store where the view is another store.

Gives us the lazy unfolding of all future states of a given store.
values.type: Store.Store s a -> Store.Store s (Store.Store s a)

values.name: extract
values.comment: View the current value.
values.type: Store.Store s a -> a

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the view.

Useful when you want to change the view of an already defined store.
values.type: (a -> b) -> Store.Store s a -> Store.Store s b

values.name: move
values.comment:
Move to the new given value.

This is how we make progress in the UI.
values.type: s -> Store.Store s a -> Store.Store s a

values.name: set
values.comment:
Replace the view.

A common pattern is to just replace the old view without depending on it:
`set x = map (\_ -> x)`
values.type: b -> Store.Store m a -> Store.Store m b

values.name: toBeginnerProgram
values.comment:
Convert to a "beginner program" for use in a `main` function.

    import Html exposing (Html)
    import Html.Events
    import Store exposing (Store)
    import String.Extra

    main : Program Never (Store Int (Html Int)) Int
    main =
        Html.beginnerProgram
            (Store.toBeginnerProgram { here = 0, view = view })

    view : Int -> Html Int
    view n =
        Html.div
            []
            [ Html.button
                [ Html.Events.onClick (n - 1) ]
                [ Html.text "-" ]
            , Html.div
                []
                [ Html.text (String.Extra.fromInt n) ]
            , Html.button
                [ Html.Events.onClick (n + 1) ]
                [ Html.text "+" ]
            ]

View this example on Ellie: <https://ellie-app.com/cDGbmY8Ca1/0>
values.type: Store.Store s (Html.Html a) -> { model : Store.Store s (Html.Html a) , update : s -> Store.Store s (Html.Html a) -> Store.Store s (Html.Html a) , view : Store.Store s (Html.Html a) -> Html.Html a }

name: Env

aliases.name: Env
aliases.comment:
Pack together the current value along with a computed view of said value.

We can specialize the `a` to be `Html a`
and get something that works for top level programs.

We can also not do that.
We can describe many UIs and they don't have to be `Html a`.

values.name: duplicate
values.comment:
Create a new env where the view is another env.

Gives us the lazy unfolding of all future states of a given env.
values.type: Env.Env e a -> Env.Env e (Env.Env e a)

values.name: extract
values.comment: View the current value.
values.type: Env.Env e a -> a

values.name: map
values.comment:
Transform the view.

Useful when you want to change the view of an already defined env.
values.type: (a -> b) -> Env.Env e a -> Env.Env e b

values.name: move
values.comment:
Move to the new given value.

This is how we make progress in the UI.
values.type: e -> Env.Env e a -> Env.Env e a

values.name: set
values.comment:
Replace the view.

A common pattern is to just replace the old view without depending on it:
`set x = map (\_ -> x)`
values.type: b -> Env.Env s a -> Env.Env s b

values.name: toBeginnerProgram
values.comment:
Convert to a "beginner program" for use in a `main` function.

    import Env exposing (Env)
    import Html exposing (Html)
    import Html.Events
    import String.Extra

    main : Program Never (Env Int (Int -> Html Int)) Int
    main =
        Html.beginnerProgram
            (Env.toBeginnerProgram { here = 0, view = view })

    view : Int -> Html Int
    view n =
        Html.div
            []
            [ Html.button
                [ Html.Events.onClick (n - 1) ]
                [ Html.text "-" ]
            , Html.div
                []
                [ Html.text (String.Extra.fromInt n) ]
            , Html.button
                [ Html.Events.onClick (n + 1) ]
                [ Html.text "+" ]
            ]

View this example on Ellie: <https://ellie-app.com/fLBqHbdNLa1/0>
values.type: Env.Env e (e -> Html.Html a) -> { model : Env.Env e (e -> Html.Html a) , update : e -> Env.Env e (e -> Html.Html a) -> Env.Env e (e -> Html.Html a) , view : Env.Env e (e -> Html.Html a) -> Html.Html a }
